p: Inflammatory cytokines such as IFNγ, IFNα, IL‐2, IL‐2R, IL‐6, IL‐7, IL‐12, IL‐15, IL‐17, and IL‐18 have been shown to be upregulated during acute CHIKF. 17 Moreover, high levels of IL‐15 (a T‐cell growth factor), 30 IL‐2R (produced upon T cell activation), 31 CXCL9 and CXCL10 (chemokines that bind to CXCR3 primarily expressed on activated T lymphocytes) 32 suggested the involvement of T cell responses during the acute phase of disease. Transcriptomics analysis in CHIKV mouse models revealed overlapping pro‐inflammatory gene expression signatures with RA patients. 20 Similarly, canonical pathways analysis showed shared patterns involving monocyte/macrophages, NK cell, B cell, and T cell signaling. 20 Among T cells, CD4 + helper T cells have been associated with acute CHIKF and RA. It has been shown that CHIKV infection triggers strong IFNγ‐producing CD4 + T cell responses (Th1). 13 This subset was also reported in the synovium of a patient displaying chronic CHIKV‐induced inflammation. 18 Similarly, Th1‐polarized cells have been shown to preferentially accumulate in RA joints. 21 Collectively, these observations supported the idea that CHIKV‐induced joint swelling and RA could be mediated by pathogenic host immune responses in a similar fashion.
